channel.title: Algorithm Problem 2
channel.description:
Consider the following game: we put a single king on the upper-left square of a standard chess board. On each turn a player may move the king one square down, to the right, or diagonally own-right (but no other direction). The players take turns moving the king (there is no passing), with the winner being the player who moves the king onto the bottom-right square. If the player who moves ﬁrst knows what he is doing, he will always win. Prove it.
But before you can prove it, you need a system to follow so that as the first player you always win. It is easier than it sounds, can you do it? :D

item.title: Algorithm Problem 2
item.dc:creator: @Bang_Train Bang Train
item.description:
@Bang_Train wrote:

i think mine does basically the same thing

Read full topic

item.title: Algorithm Problem 2
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Solution:

  1. Player 1 moves diagonally down and right
  2. Player 1 copies Player 2’s moves the rest of the game

This ensures that Player 1 is the winner every time.

Bang Train’s is similar, and might work, I would have to test it out.

Read full topic

item.title: Algorithm Problem 2
item.dc:creator: @Bang_Train Bang Train
item.description:
@Bang_Train wrote:

player 1 moves diagnally down right
player 1 moves either right or down never diagonal unless player2 moves diagonal

that makes sure the moves are even and player 1 wins

item.title: Algorithm Problem 2
item.dc:creator: @regecks1 regecks`
item.description:
@regecks1 wrote:

No, both players are using the same piece.

The objective of the game is to be the LAST to take a turn, to move onto the other corner square.

because once the first person is on the diagonal the other cannot move onto it[And that is exactly what the other person needs to do].

item.title: Algorithm Problem 2
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Ok, let me attempt to clarify. For example, if I wanted an ‘algorithm’ to calculate the price of a $200 item after you take off 70%, I could say you do it in a few steps:

  1. take half off, now the item is $100
  2. take off 10%, now the item is $80
  3. take off 10% again, now the item is $60

The answer is $60.

So for this problem, perhaps the steps would be like.

  1. first move right
  2. stay on white squares until the end by moving right every move.

Something like that.

Read full topic

item.title: Algorithm Problem 2
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

0 - player1[0, 0] - 0 - player2[8, 8] 1 - player1[1, 1] - 1 - player2[7, 7] 2 - player1[2, 2] - 2 - player2[6, 6] 3 - player1[3, 3] - 3 - player2[5, 5] 4 - player1[3, 4] - 4 - player2[5, 4] 5 - player1[4, 5] - 5 - player2[4, 3] 6 - player1[5, 6] - 6 - player2[3, 2] 7 - player1[6, 7] - 7 - player2[2, 1] 8 - player1[7, 8] - 8 - player2[1, 0] 9 - player1[8, 8] player1 wins

the “number -” indicated the move number
its the first to reach the opposite side

are we supposed to go through the steps mopar? is this similar to your solution?

int[] player1 = {0, 0}, player2 = {8, 8}; for(int x = 0; x < 10; ++x){ if(player1[0] == 8 && player1[1] == 8) { System.out.println(x + " - player1[" + player1[0] + ", " + player1[1] + "]"); System.out.println("player1 wins"); break; } if(player2[0] == 0 && player2[1] == 0) { System.out.println(x + " - player2[" + player2[0] + ", " + player2[1] + "]"); System.out.println("player2 wins"); break; } System.out.println(x + " - player1[" + player1[0] + ", " + player1[1] + "] - " + x + " - player2[" + player2[0] + ", " + player2[1] + "]"); if(player1[1] == 8) { player1[0]++; continue; } if(player2[1] == 0) { player2[0]--; continue; } if(player1[1] + 1 == player2[1] - 1){ player1[1]++; player2[1]--; } else { player1[0]++; player1[1]++; player2[0]--; player2[1]--; } }

Read full topic

item.title: Algorithm Problem 2
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

It is actually very easy in the end.

A hint is to fix your first move, and then go from there. One of our first ideas was the solution, but we rejected it at first because we didn’t fix our first move.

edit:
At the 24 hour mark I will post a big hint if no one has solved it yet.

Read full topic
